comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: In 1911, Harry Nelson Atwood (1883-1967) landed a plane on the White House lawn to accept an award from President William Howard Taft.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: "Harry N. Atwood on His Record Breaking Trip from St. Louis to New York, 1265 miles, August 14 to 25, 1911" – From postcard – Aerofiles "By 1911, Harry Atwood, a student of the Wright brothers, had become one of America's most celebrated aviators. He stunned New Yorkers with his daredevil flight among Manhattan's skyscrapers and thrilled the country when he landed his biplane on the South Lawn of the White House. His 1911 record-setting distance flights from Boston to Washington and from St. Louis to New York brought international fame." – OhioLINK

comment.author: 36580434@N07
comment._content: Sounds like someone I would have liked to know..

comment.author: 13764723@N07
comment._content: I have a photo of my grandfather  standing near Atwood's biplane at Euclid Beach ,OH taken  August 1911. Contact me if interested.

comment.author: 81574814@N07
comment._content: 6/30/2012 We have recently purchased the site of Atwoods former mansion in Monson Mass. The curent house sits on the origional concrete foundation of the manshion, the concrete tunnel and powerhouse remain in place though the generating equipment have long ago been removed. The house is stil served by the origional gravity fed well. For intresting reading see the book Skylark by Howard Mansfield.
